elements.content: Four novel highly connected metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on d10 metals and triangular ligands, namely, [Ag7(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)2(L)­(H2O)] (1), [NaCd3(4,4′-tmbpt)­(L)2(OH)]·H2O (2), [Cd3(3,3′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]·3.5H2O (3), and [Cd3(3,4′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]·1.5H2O (4) (H3L = 5-(4-carboxybenzyloxy)­isophthalic acid, 4,4′-tmbpt = 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 3,3′-tmbpt = 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3,5-bis­(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, and 3,4′-tmbpt = 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3-(3-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) (3,12)-connected net based on heptanuclear [Ag7(COO)7] units. Compound 2 displays a 3D (3,4,10)-connected net constructed by tetranuclear [NaCd3(μ3-OH)­(COO)5]+ units. Compound 3 exhibits a 3D (3,4,8)-connected net based on binuclear [Cd2(COO)2] units. Compound 4 is a 3D binodal (3,9)-connected framework constructed by trinuclear [Cd3(COO)4] units. The diverse structures of compounds 1–4 indicate that the central metals and the N-donor ligands have significant effects on the final structures. The photoluminescent properties of compounds 1–4 have been studied in detail. Remarkably, compounds 1, 2, and 4 exhibit photocatalytic activities for degradation of dye under UV light irradiation and show good stabilities toward UV-light photocatalysis.

The analysis of topology is not only an effective tool for simplifying the complicated structures but also plays an important role in the rational design of certain MOFs with desirable properties. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of current interest because of their potential applications and intriguing architectures. The analysis of topology is not only an effective tool for simplifying the complicated structures but also plays an important role in the rational design of certain MOFs with desirable properties. Up to now, a number of MOFs with fascinating structures have been prepared, and their topologies have been defined by Wells and O'Keeffe et al. However, most of the reported MOFs are based on low-connected (<8) nodes. Thus, intense interest has been paid to MOFs with highly connected nets (≥8). The construction of MOFs with highly connected numbers remains a challenge because of the limited coordination numbers of single metal centers and steric hindrances of the most commonly used organic ligands.

elements.content: It is well-known that the construction of MOFs is mainly dependent on the combination of several factors, such as the organic ligands, solvents, and metal atoms. The polycarboxylate ligands, as good candidates for the construction of MOFs, have aroused a good deal of interest from chemists. Among the polycarboxylates, the flexible 5-(4-carboxybenzyloxy)­isophthalic acid (H3L) is a good candidate for the construction of MOFs with novel architectures (Scheme ). For example, the flexible H3L possesses the rigid isophthalic acid and benzoic acid moieties, which can exhibit a great variety of coordination modes. On the other hand, the multidentate N-donor ligands 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (4,4′-tmbpt), 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3,5-bis­(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (3,3′-tmbpt) and 1-((1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­methyl)-3-(3-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole) (3,4′-tmbpt) (Scheme ) were chosen for the following reason: the rigid pyridyl and flexible triazolyl groups can provide multidentate metal-binding sites and diverse coordination modes.

elements.content: In this work, four novel highly connected MOFs based on H3L, tmbpt ligands, and d10 metal centers, namely, [Ag7(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)2(L)­(H2O)] (1), [NaCd3(4,4′-tmbpt)­(L)2(OH)]·H2O (2), [Cd3(3,3′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]·3.5H2O (3), and [Cd3(3,4′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]·1.5H2O (4), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by infrared spectra (IR), elemental analyses, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. In addition, the optical band gaps, photoluminescent and photocatalytic behaviors of compounds 1–4 have been investigated.
elements.clean_text: In this work, four novel highly connected MOFs based on H3L, tmbpt ligands, and d10 metal centers, namely, [Ag7(4,4'-tmbpt)(HL)2(L)(H2O)] (1), [NaCd3(4,4'-tmbpt)(L)2(OH)]⋅H2O (2), [Cd3(3,3'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O (3), and [Cd3(3,4'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (4), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by infrared spectra (IR), elemental analyses, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. In addition, the optical band gaps, photoluminescent and photocatalytic behaviors of compounds 1-4 have been investigated.

elements.content: H3L was prepared by the procedures reported. The N-donor ligands were prepared by standard procedures with a modification. Other reagents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received. A Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to collect microanalytical data. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 600 °C under nitrogen. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer FLS-920 spectrometer at room temperature. PXRD patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°. Diffuse reflectivity spectra were collected on a finely ground sample with a Cary 500 spectrophotometer equipped with a 110 mm diameter integrating sphere, which were measured from 200 to 800 nm using barium sulfate (BaSO4) as a standard with 100% reflectance. Photocatalytic experiments in aqueous solutions were carried out in typical processes. A suspension containing compounds 1–4 (30 mg) and 200 mL of methylene blue (MB) (5 × 10–5 mol L–1) solution was stirred in the dark for about 30 min to ensure the establishment of adsorption equilibrium before irradiation. It was then stirred continuously under a 125 W Hg lamp. Every 15 min, 3 mL of samples were taken out of the reactor and separated through centrifugation to remove suspended catalyst particles and then subjected to spectroscopic measurement on the UV–vis spectrometer. The concentration of organic dye was estimated by the absorbance at 665 nm, which directly relates to the structure change of its chromophore.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

H3L was prepared by the procedures reported. The N-donor ligands were prepared by standard procedures with a modification. Other reagents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received. A Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer was used to collect microanalytical data. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 600 °C under nitrogen. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer FLS-920 spectrometer at room temperature. PXRD patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°. Diffuse reflectivity spectra were collected on a finely ground sample with a Cary 500 spectrophotometer equipped with a 110 mm diameter integrating sphere, which were measured from 200 to 800 nm using barium sulfate (BaSO4) as a standard with 100% reflectance. Photocatalytic experiments in aqueous solutions were carried out in typical processes. A suspension containing compounds 1-4 (30 mg) and 200 mL of methylene blue (MB) (5 × 10-5 mol L-1) solution was stirred in the dark for about 30 min to ensure the establishment of adsorption equilibrium before irradiation. It was then stirred continuously under a 125 W Hg lamp. Every 15 min, 3 mL of samples were taken out of the reactor and separated through centrifugation to remove suspended catalyst particles and then subjected to spectroscopic measurement on the UV-vis spectrometer. The concentration of organic dye was estimated by the absorbance at 665 nm, which directly relates to the structure change of its chromophore.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>7</sub>(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)<sub>2</sub>(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of H3L (0.064 g, 0.2 mmol), AgNO3 (0.102 g, 0.6 mmol), NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol), 4,4′-tmbpt (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the mixture had been cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h–1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 57% yield. Anal. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1–4 were recorded on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program. Non-hydrogen atoms of the compounds were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. All hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model with d(C–H) = 0.93 Å, U iso = 1.2U eq(C) for aromatic and d(C–H) = 0.97 Å, U iso = 1.2U eq(C) for CH2 atoms. Hydrogen atom of the carboxylate group in 1 were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model with d(O–H) = 0.82 Å, U iso = 1.5U eq(O). Water and hydroxyl hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined as riding atoms with d(O–H) = 0.826–0.877 Å and U iso = 1.5U eq(O). The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters of compounds 1–4 are summarized in Table . The maximum residual electron density is 2.11 e Å–3 at 1.0 Å from Ag2 for compound 1, 1.08 e Å–3 at 1.0 Å from Cd1 and 1.02 e Å–3 at 1.0 Å from Cd2 for compound 2, and 1.31 e Å–3 at 1.1 Å from Cd3 for compound 3. These residual electron densities can be interpreted as Fourier truncation errors.

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1–4 are listed in Tables S1–S4 (). The topologies of compounds 1–4 were analyzed by using the OLEX program.

Structure of [Ag<sub>7</sub>(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)<sub>2</sub>(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>1</bold>)

Compound 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) (3,12)-connected net based on heptanuclear [Ag7(COO)7] units. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of seven Ag­(I) ions, one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, one L anion, two HL anions, and one coordinating water molecule. As shown in Figure a, Ag1 and Ag2 are three-coordinated in approximate “T’’-shaped coordination environments. Ag1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different HL anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, while Ag2 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two L anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand. Ag3, Ag4, Ag6, and Ag7 show similar tetrahedral coordination geometries. Ag6 and Ag7 are coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two L anions and two HL anions, and Ag3 is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two distinct HL anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, while Ag4 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one L anion, two HL anions and one water molecule. Ag5 is five coordinated in a trigonal biyramid coordination sphere, completed by five oxygen atoms from four different HL anions. The Ag–O bond lengths vary from 2.134 to 2.860 Å, and the Ag–N bond distances range from 2.139 to 2.411 Å. All Ag–O and Ag–N bond distances are within the normal ranges observed in other Ag­(I) complexes. Seven Ag­(I) ions are connected by seven carboxylate groups to form a heptanuclear unit [Ag7(COO)7] (Figure b). Each heptanuclear Ag­(I) unit is surrounded by 12 organic ligands (three 4,4′-tmbpt ligands, two HL and seven L anions), and each organic ligand (tmbpt ligand, HL and L anion) is connected to three heptanuclear Ag­(I) units (Figure c). In this way, the HL and L anions link the heptanuclear units to form a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure d), which is further extended by the 4,4′-tmbpt ligands to generate a 3D framework.

Results and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1-4 are listed in Tables S1-S4 (). The topologies of compounds 1-4 were analyzed by using the OLEX program. 

Structure of [Ag7(4,4'-tmbpt)(HL)2(L)(H2O)] (1)

Compound 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) (3,12)-connected net based on heptanuclear [Ag7(COO)7] units. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of seven Ag(I) ions, one 4,4'-tmbpt ligand, one L anion, two HL anions, and one coordinating water molecule. As shown in Figure a, Ag1 and Ag2 are three-coordinated in approximate "T''-shaped coordination environments. Ag1 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two different HL anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4'-tmbpt ligand, while Ag2 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two L anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4'-tmbpt ligand. Ag3, Ag4, Ag6, and Ag7 show similar tetrahedral coordination geometries. Ag6 and Ag7 are coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two L anions and two HL anions, and Ag3 is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two distinct HL anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4'-tmbpt ligand, while Ag4 is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from one L anion, two HL anions and one water molecule. Ag5 is five coordinated in a trigonal biyramid coordination sphere, completed by five oxygen atoms from four different HL anions. The Ag-O bond lengths vary from 2.134 to 2.860 Å, and the Ag-N bond distances range from 2.139 to 2.411 Å. All Ag-O and Ag-N bond distances are within the normal ranges observed in other Ag(I) complexes. Seven Ag(I) ions are connected by seven carboxylate groups to form a heptanuclear unit [Ag7(COO)7] (Figure b). Each heptanuclear Ag(I) unit is surrounded by 12 organic ligands (three 4,4'-tmbpt ligands, two HL and seven L anions), and each organic ligand (tmbpt ligand, HL and L anion) is connected to three heptanuclear Ag(I) units (Figure c). In this way, the HL and L anions link the heptanuclear units to form a two-dimensional (2D) layer (Figure d), which is further extended by the 4,4'-tmbpt ligands to generate a 3D framework.

elements.content: From the topological point of view, the heptanuclear unit [Ag7(COO)7] can be defined as a 12-connected node, the organic ligands can be regarded as two kinds of 3-connected nodes. Thus, the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (3,12)-connected framework with (43)­(4·62)­(421·626·819) topology (Figure e).

elements.content: It should be pointed out that (3,12)-connected nets are very rare because the higher-connected polynuclear units are difficult to form. Up to now, although few examples of (3,12)-connected MOFs based on Zn­(II), Co­(II), Be­(II), and lanthanide polynuclear units have been reported, the ones based on polynuclear Ag­(I) units have not been observed. Thus, compound 1 represents the first example of a (3,12)-connected framework based on polynuclear Ag­(I) units.

elements.content: Compound 2 displays a 3D (3,4,10)-connected net constructed by tetranuclear [NaCd3(μ3-OH)­(COO)5]+ units. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one Na­(I) ion, three Cd­(II) ions, one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, two L anions, one hydroxyl group, and one lattice water molecule. The hydroxyl group was determined by the bond-valence calculation. The bond valence sum (BVS) value of O8 is 1.12, suggesting that this oxygen atom is monoprotonated (OH). As shown in Figure a, Na­(I) ion is five-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four different L anions and one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand. Cd1 is seven-coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, and six oxygen atoms from three different L anions and one hydroxyl group. Both Cd2 and Cd3 are six-coordinated in distorted octahedral coordination geometries, but their coordination environments are entirely different. Cd2 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, and five oxygen atoms from four individual L anions and one hydroxyl group. Cd3 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one 4,4′-tmbpt ligand, and five oxygen atoms from three distinct L anions. The Na–O distances are in the range of 2.359(6)–2.451(6) Å and the Na–N bond length is 2.699(6) Å. The Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances are in the ranges of 2.182(5)–2.628(5) and 2.219(6)–2.333(4) Å, respectively. Three crystallographically distinct Cd­(II) ions and one Na­(I) ion are held together by one hydroxyl group and five carboxylate groups to form a tetranuclear [NaCd3(μ3-OH)­(COO)5]+ unit (Figure b). Each tetranuclear unit is surrounded by 10 organic ligands (four 4,4′-tmbpt ligands and six L anions), and each 4,4′-tmbpt ligand is connected to four tetranuclear units, while each L anion is coordinated with three tetranuclear units (Figure c). In this manner, the L anions connected the tetranuclear units to form a 2D layer (Figure d), which is extended by the 4,4′-tmbpt ligands to furnish a 3D framework.

elements.content: The resulting trinodal (3,4,10)-connected topology is a rare case of trinodal 10-connected net. Up to now, the uninodal network topologies have been extensively studied, and the construction of binodal highly connected framework also has been realized recently. However, the trinodal highly connected MOFs are exceedingly scarce. To the best of our knowledge, only three examples of trinodal 10-connected MOFs, namely, (3,6,10)-, (4,6,10)-, and (4,5,10)-connected topologies, have been reported so far.

elements.content: Compound 3 exhibits a 3D (3,4,8)-connected net with (4·6·8)­(62·84)­(44·67·815·102) topology. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains three Cd­(II) ions, two 3,3′-tmbpt ligands, two L anions, and five and a half water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 and Cd2 show similar octahedral coordination geometries, completed by four oxygen atoms from three individual L anions and two nitrogen atoms from two distinct 3,3′-tmbpt ligands. Cd3 is six-coordinated in an octahedral coordination environment, defined by two nitrogen atoms from two different 3,3′-tmbpt ligands, and four oxygen atoms from two individual L anions and two water molecules. The Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances are in the ranges of 2.240(4)–2.465(4) and 2.313(4)–2.392(4) Å, respectively. Cd1 and Cd2 are held together by two carboxylate groups to yield a binuclear [Cd2(COO)2] unit. Each binuclear unit is linked by eight organic ligands (four 3,3′-tmbpt ligands and four L anions), each 3,3′-tmbpt ligand and each L anion connect with three binuclear units, and each Cd3 coordinates with four organic ligands (two 3,3′-tmbpt ligands and two L anions) (Figure b). Thus, the binuclear units are connected by the L anions to generate a 2D layer (Figure c), which is further extended by the 3,3′-tmbpt ligands into a 3D framework.

elements.content: Compound 4 is a binodal 3D (3,9)-connected framework based on trinuclear units. The asymmetric unit of 4 contains three Cd­(II) ions, two 3,4′-tmbpt ligands, two L anions, and two and a half water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 is seven-coordinated in a pentagonal bipyramid coordination environment, coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one 3,4′-tmbpt ligand, and six oxygen atoms from three distinct L anions and one water molecule. Although both Cd2 and Cd3 are six-coordinated in octahedral coordination geometries, their coordination environments are completely different. Cd2 is coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one 3,4′-tmbpt ligand, and five oxygen atoms from four individual L anions. Cd3 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct 3,4′-tmbpt ligands, and four oxygen atoms from three different L anions. The Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.284(4) to 2.400(4) Å, and the Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.222(3) to 2.648(4) Å. Three Cd­(II) ions are connected together by four carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear [Cd3(COO)4] unit. It is interesting to note that each trinuclear unit is surrounded by 10 organic ligands (six L anions and four 3,4′-tmbpt ligands), but it is virtually linked to nine nearest neighbors, because a pair of L ligands form one “double-bridge”. Each L anion connects to three trinuclear units, while the 3,4′-tmbpt ligands act as linkers (Figure b). In this way, the trinuclear units are bridged by the L anions to furnish a 2D layer (Figure c), which is further linked by the 3,4′-tmbpt ligands to yield a 3D framework.

elements.content: Although a large number of examples of 3-, 4-, and 6-connected networks have been reported, the ones with 3D 9-connected networks are relatively rare. Up to now, only a few 9-connected frameworks, such as uninodal ncb, ncd, and vnd topologies, binodal (3,9)-connected frameworks and trinodal (3,4,9)- and (4,5,9)-connected nets, have been reported. To the best of our knowledge, among the reported binodal (3,9)-connected frameworks, only one example is a metal–organic compound. Thus, compound 4 represents the second (3,9)-connected MOF.

elements.content: From the structure descriptions above, we can see that the N-donor ligands play important roles in the formation of the final structures. In this study, three kinds of N-donor ligands, namely, 4,4′-tmbpt, 3,3′-tmbpt, and 3,4′-tmbpt, were used to investigate the effect of positions of the pyridyl groups on the structures. Take compounds [NaCd3(4,4′-tmbpt)­(L)2(OH)]·H2O (2), [Cd3(3,3′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]·3.5H2O (3), and [Cd3(3,4′-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]·1.5H2O (4) for example. Although 4,4′-tmbpt, 3,3′-tmbpt, and 3,4′-tmbpt contain two priydyl groups, the positions of the priydyl groups are completely different. The difference in the positions of their priydyl groups is the main factor that led to the difference in the structures of 2, 3, and 4. In 2, 3, and 4, the tricarboxylate anions link the metal centers into 2D layers, but the tmbpt ligands with differently oriented pyridyl groups connect the 2D layers from different directions to generate three different 3D structures. In 2, the 4,4′-tmbpt ligands bridge the layers to form a 3D (3,4,10)-connected net, while, in 3 and 4, the 3,3′-tmbpt and the 3,4′-tmbpt ligands extend the 2D layers into 3D (3,4,8)- and (3,9)-connected frameworks, respectively. Moreover, the twist degrees of the tmbpt ligands, which are shown by the dihedral angles between the three peripheral rings and the central triazolyl rings (θ1 represents the dihedral angle between the pyridyl group on the 3-position and the central triazolyl ring; θ2 represents the dihedral angle between the pyridyl group on the 5-position and the central triazolyl ring; θ3 represents the dihedral angle between the peripheral triazolyl ring and the central triazolyl ring), can also influence the final structures of 1–4. As shown in Table , the three peripheral rings and the central triazolyl rings of the tmbpt ligands can show different θ angles when they coordinate with the central metal atoms. The θ angles of 3 (θ1 = 28.1/26.3, θ2 = 55.1/50.2, and θ3 = 57.2/52.6°) are completely different from the corresponding ones of 1 (θ1 = 8.7, θ2 = 30.8, and θ3 = 73.1°), 2 (θ1 = 10.8, θ2 = 35.4, and θ3 = 82.9°), and 4 (θ1 = 11.2/6.6, θ2 = 34.8/26.7, and θ3 = 70.7/83.2°). The difference in the θ angles between 3 and 1, 2 and 4 is mainly attributed to the changes in the positions of the pyridyl-N atoms. For example, in 3, two pyridyl-N atoms of 3,3′-tmbpt are on the 3-positions, whereas, in 1 and 2, the ones of 4,4′-tmbpt are on the 4-positions. Therefore, when coordinated with metals, the twist angles of tmbpt will change to conform to the central metals because of the variations in the positions of the pyridyl-N atoms. It should be noted that the θ angles from one kind of tmbpt in 4 are near to those of 1, while the other ones are close to those of 2. The θ1 and θ2 angles of 1 are very close to those of 2, whereas their θ3 angles are different. The similar θ1 and θ2 angles between 1 and 2 can be attributed to the same positions of the two pyridyl-N atoms. However, their different θ3 angles may come from the presence of the flexible −CH2– spacer between the peripheral triazolyl ring and the central triazolyl ring. It is easy to understand that the twist degrees of the tmbpt ligands are an obvious factor that results in the structure differences in 1–4.

In this study, three kinds of N-donor ligands, namely, 4,4'-tmbpt, 3,3'-tmbpt, and 3,4'-tmbpt, were used to investigate the effect of positions of the pyridyl groups on the structures. Take compounds [NaCd3(4,4'-tmbpt)(L)2(OH)]⋅H2O (2), [Cd3(3,3'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O (3), and [Cd3(3,4'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (4) for example. On the other hand, the central metals have significant effects on the resultant structures of the MOFs. The differences in the coordination numbers of the central metals are the key reasons for the structural diversities. For example, compounds [Ag7(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)2(L)­(H2O)] (1) and [NaCd3(4,4′-tmbpt)­(L)2(OH)]·H2O (2) show the effects of the central metals on the final structures. The coordination numbers of the Ag­(I) ions are lower than those of the Na­(I) and Cd­(II) ions. The Ag­(I) ions in compound 1 adopt the coordination numbers of 3, 4, and 5. However, the Na­(I) ions in 2 show the coordination number of 5, and the Cd­(II) ions exhibit the coordination numbers of 6 and 7. Clearly, these differences led to the formation of two structurally different compounds 1 and 2.

The coordination numbers of the Ag(I) ions are lower than those of the Na(I) and Cd(II) ions. The Ag(I) ions in compound 1 adopt the coordination numbers of 3, 4, and 5. The experimental PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the corresponding simulated ones, implying that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same ().
elements.clean_text:
PXRD Patterns and Thermal Analyses

In order to confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, the PXRD patterns of compounds 1-4 were recorded. The experimental PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the corresponding simulated ones, implying that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same ().

elements.content: To estimate the thermal stabilities of compounds 1–4, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). The experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, as shown in . For compound 1, the weight loss of 1.7% from 21 to 237 °C is attributed to the loss of one water molecule (calcd 0.9%). Decomposition of the organic ligands occurs from 237 to 600 °C, leading to the formation of Ag2O as the residue (obsd 44.5%, calcd 40.2%). For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of one water molecule is observed from room temperature to 97 °C (obsd 1.8%, calcd 1.4%). There is no further weight loss from 97 to 307 °C. After that temperature, the organic components start to decompose. The remaining residue corresponding to the formation of CdO and Na2O is 33.3% (calcd 31.3%). Compound 3 undergoes dehydration in the temperature range of 30–132 °C (obsd 6.6%, calcd 5.9%). The framework decomposes in the temperature range of 330–516 °C. The remaining weight is 21.3%, corresponding to the formation of CdO (calcd 23.0%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that the first weight loss from room temperature to 79 °C is assigned to the loss of water molecules (obsd 3.2%, calcd 2.8%). The second weight loss in the temperature range of 199–515 °C can be assigned to the release of the organic ligands. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 28.8%, calcd 27.8%).

elements.content: Some MOFs have been reported to be promising semiconductive materials in the previous literature. Inspired by this, we investigated the conductivity potentials of compounds 1–4. The measurements of diffuse reflectivity for 1–4 were performed to obtain their band gaps (E g), which were defined as the intersection point between the energy axis and the line extrapolated from the linear portion of the adsorption edge in a plot of Kubelka–Munk function F versus energy E. Kubelka–Munk function, F = (1 – R)2/2R, was transformed from the recorded diffuse reflectance data, where R is the reflectance of an infinitely thick layer at a given wavelength. The F against E plots are shown in Figure , and the E g values assessed from the steep absorption edge for compounds 1–4 are 3.36, 3.44, 3.45, and 3.50 eV, respectively, which indicate that compounds 1–4 are potential wide gap semiconductive materials.

Optical Band Gaps

Some MOFs have been reported to be promising semiconductive materials in the previous literature. Inspired by this, we investigated the conductivity potentials of compounds 1-4. The measurements of diffuse reflectivity for 1-4 were performed to obtain their band gaps (E g), which were defined as the intersection point between the energy axis and the line extrapolated from the linear portion of the adsorption edge in a plot of Kubelka-Munk function F versus energy E. Kubelka-Munk function, F = (1 - R)2/2R, was transformed from the recorded diffuse reflectance data, where R is the reflectance of an infinitely thick layer at a given wavelength. The F against E plots are shown in Figure , and the E g values assessed from the steep absorption edge for compounds 1-4 are 3.36, 3.44, 3.45, and 3.50 eV, respectively, which indicate that compounds 1-4 are potential wide gap semiconductive materials.

elements.content: Luminescent properties of compounds with d10 metal centers have attracted much interest due to their potential applications in electroluminescent display, chemical sensors, and photochemistry. Therefore, in this work, the photoluminescent properties of compounds 1–4 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The emission peaks are shown in Figure S3 ().
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Luminescent properties of compounds with d10 metal centers have attracted much interest due to their potential applications in electroluminescent display, chemical sensors, and photochemistry. Therefore, in this work, the photoluminescent properties of compounds 1-4 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The emission peaks are shown in Figure S3 ().

elements.content: The main emission peaks of the free H3L, 4,4′-tmbpt, 3,3′-tmbpt, and 3,4′-tmbpt ligands are at 415 nm (λex = 368 nm), 458 nm (λex = 337 nm), 441 nm (λex = 344 nm), and 554 nm (λex = 328 nm), respectively. These emission peaks may be assigned to the π*–n or π*−π transition. Compounds 1–4 show emission peaks at 579 nm (λex = 363 nm), 428 nm (λex = 352 nm), 414 nm (λex = 357 nm), and 411 nm (λex = 354 nm), respectively. The emission peaks of 2–4 are near to that of the free H3L, so the emissions of the three compounds can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emissions. However, in compound 1, the emission peak is highly red-shifted compared to the free H3L and the 4,4′-tmbpt ligands. The observed red shift of the emission maximum may be caused by the following reasons: (i) organic ligands may change their highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels after coordination to metal centers; (ii) charge transfer occurs between organic ligands and metal centers.

These emission peaks may be assigned to the π*-n or π*-π transition. Compounds 1-4 show emission peaks at 579 nm (λex = 363 nm), 428 nm (λex = 352 nm), 414 nm (λex = 357 nm), and 411 nm (λex = 354 nm), respectively. The emission peaks of 2-4 are near to that of the free H3L, so the emissions of the three compounds can probably be attributed to the intraligand fluorescent emissions. However, in compound 1, the emission peak is highly red-shifted compared to the free H3L and the 4,4'-tmbpt ligands. The observed red shift of the emission maximum may be caused by the following reasons: (i) organic ligands may change their highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels after coordination to metal centers; (ii) charge transfer occurs between organic ligands and metal centers.

elements.content: Photocatalysts have attracted much attention due to their potential applications in purifying water and air by thoroughly decomposing organic compounds. Herein, MB, as a model of dye contaminant, was selected for evaluating the activities of photocatalysts in the purification of wastewater. We have investigated the photocatalytic performances of compounds 1–4 for the photodegradation of MB under UV irradiation. Compounds 1, 2, and 4 have good photocatalytic activities. However, no photocatalytic behavior was observed for compound 3. The complex structures, such as the numbers of the coordinated water molecules, the coordination environments of the central metals, the extent of the conjugation and the sizes of the metal–oxygen clusters, are the main factor that influences their photocatalytic activities. Although the composite of 3 is greatly related to that of 4, the numbers of their water molecules, the coordination environments of their central metals, and the sizes of their Cd-oxygen clusters are entirely different. For example, compound 3 contains the binuclear [Cd2(COO)2] units, while compound 4 possesses the trinuclear [Cd3(COO)3] units. Therefore, it can be surmised that the relatively large trinuclear [Cd3(COO)3] units of 4 aid in the transport of excited holes/electrons to the surface to initiate the photocatalytic decomposition reaction with MB. Finally, this discrepancy in the crystal structures of 3 and 4 led to the difference in their photocatalytic activities.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Properties

Photocatalysts have attracted much attention due to their potential applications in purifying water and air by thoroughly decomposing organic compounds. Herein, MB, as a model of dye contaminant, was selected for evaluating the activities of photocatalysts in the purification of wastewater. We have investigated the photocatalytic performances of compounds 1-4 for the photodegradation of MB under UV irradiation. Compounds 1, 2, and 4 have good photocatalytic activities. However, no photocatalytic behavior was observed for compound 3. The complex structures, such as the numbers of the coordinated water molecules, the coordination environments of the central metals, the extent of the conjugation and the sizes of the metal-oxygen clusters, are the main factor that influences their photocatalytic activities. Although the composite of 3 is greatly related to that of 4, the numbers of their water molecules, the coordination environments of their central metals, and the sizes of their Cd-oxygen clusters are entirely different. For example, compound 3 contains the binuclear [Cd2(COO)2] units, while compound 4 possesses the trinuclear [Cd3(COO)3] units. Therefore, it can be surmised that the relatively large trinuclear [Cd3(COO)3] units of 4 aid in the transport of excited holes/electrons to the surface to initiate the photocatalytic decomposition reaction with MB. Finally, this discrepancy in the crystal structures of 3 and 4 led to the difference in their photocatalytic activities.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the absorption peaks of MB decreased obviously along with the prolonging of reaction time. In addition, the concentrations of MB (C) versus reaction times (t) of compounds 1, 2, and 4 are plotted in Figure . It can be seen that the photocatalytic activities increase from 24% (without any catalyst) to 73% for 1, 65% for 2, and 54% for 4 after 1.5 h of irradiation. These results suggest that compounds 1, 2, and 4 may be good candidates for photocatalytic degradation of MB. Control experiments were carried out for the compounds. Take compound 2 for example. The CdCl2·2H2O and the 4,4′-tmbpt ligand were added to the MB solution under UV irradiation, respectively. However, they did not show observable photocatalytic activities. In addition, the photostabilities of compounds 1, 2, and 4 were monitored by using powder PXRD patterns during the course of photocatalytic reactions (Figure S4 in ). The PXRD patterns are nearly identical to that of the original compounds. It indicates that compounds 1, 2, and 4 remain unchanged after the photocatalytic reactions, implying that they can be used as stable photocatalysts for the photodegradation of MB.

elements.content: The simultaneous use of the triangular 5-(4-carboxybenzyloxy)­isophthalic acid and related tmbpt ligands to react with d10 metals affords a series of interesting highly connected frameworks. These complexes display fascinating 3D (3,12)-, (3,4,10)-, (3,4,8)-, and (3,9)-connected topologies. The successful isolation of these solid materials provides intriguing examples of highly connected architectures. The multicarboxylates in compounds 1–4 effectively chelated metal ions to form polynuclear units. The different multidentate tmbpt ligands further bridged the discrete polynuclear units to yield extended highly connected frameworks. The changes in the positions of pyridyl-N atoms and the twist degrees of the tmbpt ligands are key factors for the formation of different highly connected MOFs. It is believed that the results presented here may provide a potential pathway to rational design of diverse highly connected MOFs. The photoluminescent behaviors of the compounds 1–4 imply that these complexes may be good optical materials. The photocatalytic behaviors of compounds 1, 2, and 4 indicate they may be good and stable photocatalysts for the photodegradation of MB.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The simultaneous use of the triangular 5-(4-carboxybenzyloxy)isophthalic acid and related tmbpt ligands to react with d10 metals affords a series of interesting highly connected frameworks. These complexes display fascinating 3D (3,12)-, (3,4,10)-, (3,4,8)-, and (3,9)-connected topologies. The successful isolation of these solid materials provides intriguing examples of highly connected architectures. The multicarboxylates in compounds 1-4 effectively chelated metal ions to form polynuclear units. The different multidentate tmbpt ligands further bridged the discrete polynuclear units to yield extended highly connected frameworks. The changes in the positions of pyridyl-N atoms and the twist degrees of the tmbpt ligands are key factors for the formation of different highly connected MOFs. It is believed that the results presented here may provide a potential pathway to rational design of diverse highly connected MOFs. The photoluminescent behaviors of the compounds 1-4 imply that these complexes may be good optical materials. The photocatalytic behaviors of compounds 1, 2, and 4 indicate they may be good and stable photocatalysts for the photodegradation of MB.

The N-donor ligands were synthesized according to the reported procedures with a modification ().

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>7</sub>(4,4′-tmbpt)­(HL)<sub>2</sub>(L)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of H3L (0.064 g, 0.2 mmol), AgNO3 (0.102 g, 0.6 mmol), NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol), 4,4′-tmbpt (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the mixture had been cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h–1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 57% yield. Anal. Calcd for C63H43 Ag7N8O22 (M r = 2019.14): C, 37.47; H, 2.15; N, 5.55. Found: C, 37.36; H, 2.22; N, 5.49. Syntheses

The N-donor ligands were synthesized according to the reported procedures with a modification (). 

Synthesis of [Ag7(4,4'-tmbpt)(HL)2(L)(H2O)] (1)

A mixture of H3L (0.064 g, 0.2 mmol), AgNO3 (0.102 g, 0.6 mmol), NaOH (0.024 g, 0.6 mmol), 4,4'-tmbpt (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol), and water (8 mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (15 mL) and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. After the mixture had been cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C⋅h-1, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained in 57% yield. Anal. Calcd for C63H43 Ag7N8O22 (M r = 2019.14): C, 37.47; H, 2.15; N, 5.55. Found: C, 37.36; H, 2.22; N, 5.49. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(m), 3100(w), 3022(w), 1675(m), 1644(w), 1613(m), 1555(s), 1519(m), 1473(w), 1428(w), 1390(w), 1361(s), 1321(m), 1279(m), 1257(m), 1227(m), 1172(w), 1128(w), 1060(w), 1015(w), 960(w), 846(w), 765(m), 705(w), 639(w), 518(w), 418(w).

Synthesis of [NaCd3(4,4'-tmbpt)(L)2(OH)]⋅H2O (2)

The preparation of 2 was similar to that of 1 except that Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.081 g, 0.3 mmol) was used instead of AgNO3. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in 49% yield. Anal. Calcd for C47H33Cd3NaN8O16 (M r = 1326.00): C, 42.57; H, 2.51; N, 8.45. Found: C, 42.52; H, 2.43; N, 8.55. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(m), 3124(w), 1615(s), 1542(s), 1457(m), 1396(s), 1371(s), 1272(m), 1176(w), 1129(w), 1060(w), 1017(w), 962(w), 852(w), 777(w), 760(w), 716(w), 699(w), 668(w), 636(w), 588(w), 469(w), 419(w).

Synthesis of [Cd3(3,3'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O (3)

The preparation of 3 was similar to that of 2 except that 3,3'-tmbpt (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) was used instead of 4,4'-tmbpt and the reaction temperature was 120 °C. Colorless crystals of 3 were obtained in 34% yield. Anal. Calcd for C62H53Cd3N16O19.5 (M r = 1671.40): C, 44.55; H, 3.20; N, 13.41. Found: C, 44.61; H, 3.31; N, 13.32. Synthesis of [Cd3(3,4'-tmbpt)2(L)2(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (4)

The preparation of 4 was similar to that of 3 except that 3,4'-tmbpt (0.03 g, 0.1 mmol) was used instead of 3,3'-tmbpt. Colorless crystals of 4 were obtained in 34% yield. Anal. Calcd for C62H47Cd3N16O16.5 (M r = 1617.36): C, 46.04; H, 2.94; N, 13.86. Found: C, 46.14; H, 3.01; N, 13.82. cln_elements.content:
From the topological point of view, these trinuclear units can be regarded as 9-connected nodes, the L anions can be considered as 3-connected nodes, and the 3,4′-tmbpt ligands can be viewed as linkers (Figure c). Thus, the overall 3D structure of 4 is a binodal (3,9)-connected net with (43)2(48·625·83) topology (Figure d).

To estimate the thermal stabilities of compounds 1–4, their thermal behaviors were studied by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). The experiments were performed under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, as shown in . For compound 1, the weight loss of 1.7% from 21 to 237 °C is attributed to the loss of one water molecule (calcd 0.9%). Decomposition of the organic ligands occurs from 237 to 600 °C, leading to the formation of Ag2O as the residue (obsd 44.5%, calcd 40.2%). For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the release of one water molecule is observed from room temperature to 97 °C (obsd 1.8%, calcd 1.4%). There is no further weight loss from 97 to 307 °C. After that temperature, the organic components start to decompose. The remaining residue corresponding to the formation of CdO and Na2O is 33.3% (calcd 31.3%). Compound 3 undergoes dehydration in the temperature range of 30–132 °C (obsd 6.6%, calcd 5.9%). The framework decomposes in the temperature range of 330–516 °C. The remaining weight is 21.3%, corresponding to the formation of CdO (calcd 23.0%). The TGA curve of 4 shows that the first weight loss from room temperature to 79 °C is assigned to the loss of water molecules (obsd 3.2%, calcd 2.8%). The second weight loss in the temperature range of 199–515 °C can be assigned to the release of the organic ligands. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 28.8%, calcd 27.8%).

A Series of Highly Connected
Metal–Organic Frameworks Based on Triangular Ligands and d10 Metals: Syntheses, Structures, Photoluminescence, and Photocatalysis
